posts.name: Matthew Zhou
posts.cooked:
Our team is experiencing a weird issue with some of our subsystems that run on Falcon 500s. The Falcon that runs the extendable arm spins faster when extending the arm than retracting it. This is especially weird when the motor is fighting gravity while extending but it’s somehow moving faster than when gravity is assisting it while retracting.

This is also happening with the subsystem the controls the arms vertical movement, with the motors moving faster when opposing gravity than with gravity.

We’ve double check the firmware to make sure it’s all up to date. We’ve also tried using Phoenix Tuner to control the motors directly, but the motors were still moving at different speeds in one direction compared to another.

Any help would be appreciated.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Have you tried replacing the motor?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Matthew Zhou
posts.cooked: We have not tried that, but it will be hard to replace the motors as we are already using all of our Falcon 500 motors and they will be out of stock for the rest of the season
I’d make sure you test with the motor free spinning (ex. not connected to any mechanism or gearbox). This could be indicative of an underlying issue elsewhere.

posts.name: Berke Sinan Yetkin
posts.cooked: If you are using a constant force spring based extendable arm, you are fighting against said springs when retracting. Maybe they are too powerful?

posts.name: Matthew Zhou
posts.cooked: That’s definitely something to try out tomorrow when we get to work on the robot again. Thanks

posts.name: Matthew Zhou
posts.cooked: Unfortunately, we are not using a spring-based extendable arm, as it’s just being driven by a chain

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked: Did the falcons through Phoenix Tuner support setting different forward and reverse max speeds? Could that be the issue?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.cooked:
Do you have significant binding in your system in one direction?

Post photos, videos, and code as well. Diagnosing something like this requires ruling out quite a few things.

posts.name: Matthew Zhou
posts.cooked: Thanks for the tip! The motors had different forward and reverse max speeds from the Phoenix Tuner support settings (most likely from a previous year).
